text: And so, you know, when I read some of the documents, what I think of is that we're trying to go back to the future to what it was, because it was one UN sitting around the table working with national authorities, you know, in sort of supporting their development plan.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, the UN and I have been resident coordinator in four countries, was that I feel I spent a lot of time as resident coordinator and as resident representative of the UN in mobilizing resources because I think development has been chronically underfunded.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And the mandates that we get for development, whether it's the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals or earlier Millennium Development Goals or other mandates that we've had, remain underfunded.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so a great deal of my time was spent in mobilizing resources and as Resident coordinator, not only mobilizing resources for the undp, but for the UN country team as well.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And there's also the, you know, we come with the technical agencies of the un.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We come with, you know, technical assistance programs and projects.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But sometimes we don't get that seat at the table because the larger financial institutes, IFIs, world banks, regional development banks, they come with massive investment in the sector and so very often the ministries of finance in those other countries are more interested obviously in looking at these huge investments that come into these sectors.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So a lot of development work seems to suffer because of that.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In moving to the humanitarian side, I would say that the humanitarian side of the UN in my experience, has been the side that delivers the best it may be.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I think it is largely so that in humanitarian work the mandate is saving lives.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And in times of critical situations, there is very little that holds back, even though humanitarian appeals are never fully funded.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But nevertheless, the mission of saving lives brings more to the table than a long term development goal.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: For instance.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And in the humanitarian sector, I have seen that the interagency standing committee works well.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The cluster system of the humanitarian system, where there's a lead agency, other agencies follow support, you know, that that works well as, and bringing in the non governmental and outside workers.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So that part of the system I think is the one.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But as I say, their mandate is very strong in terms of these are life saving actions that must be done.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But I think the UN has worked out its mechanics well in this sector.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Let me move then to the final sector where I spent the last 10 years of my career, which was in peace operations.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And there I worked both in political and peacekeeping missions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In Afghanistan it was working in a political mission where the troops were NATO troops, but in Sudan we had our own UN troops.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And in Timor Leste it was primarily a policing mission with the UN police contingent working very closely with other bilateral inputs as well.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And where the UN had executive authority going back to Afghanistan immediately in the aftermath of 9 11, when the Karzai government was installed, it was very important for civil servants to be paid.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And again, this goes a little bit into that.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: You know, what do you do as quick wins and the flexibility that is required for implementation under those circumstances.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And at that time, a brilliant boss that I had, Julia Taft, who worked in the Bureau for Crisis Prevention and Recovery, said, we have civil servants.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And, you know, we sort of went through all kinds of, you know, discussions, but we were able to sort of make a real headway in saying, okay, we are going to deliver to every single civil servant in Afghanistan their first monthly salary.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So In January of 2002, in brown paper bags, cash was given to every single civil servant of Afghanistan that stayed, that remained as a kind of one off.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And this is where I think, you know, Ambassador Kimani was saying, the knowledge that we have, sometimes it is not used.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: You know, the flexibility that we had there, as I understand, didn't work in Aceh when the money was there, but the money couldn't go to those who desperately needed it at the time.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So I think these kinds of flexibility in implementation is what is needed with the peace, whether it's political or peacekeeping missions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Again, I think both Ambassador Kimani and others referred to it that when the mandates are set up, it's very important to recognize that there is expertise that already resides within the UN system in the country for a long time.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so when I went to East Timor, for example, and we saw, you know, I had large numbers of staff who were experts on injustice and protection of civilians in, you know, domestic violence.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Since that was quite a big issue in East Timor, you know, we were able to again in the context of East Timor, move that expertise to be embedded with the country team to provide the capacity that was needed to the institutions in East Timor, to the respective ministries and others in East Timor now.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And at the time that the mission was closing, we also had to do quite a lot of groundbreaking work to say let's pass on some of these resources to the country team.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And here one of the co chairs, New Zealand, knows very well how much we work to try and get community policing to continue so that when the mission stopped, that work didn't stop, but continued through the country team and continued through bilateral partners.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So these things should not be anomalies.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: These things should be the norm.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And as people have said, the knowledge exists there.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The, you know, we need to take these lessons learned.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We need to see how we can bring the system together.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And you know, in, in many cases it's been demonstrated that, that it can be done.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Lastly, on exit strategy, I'm a firm believer of that.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It was very much a part of the HIPPO report recommendations as well.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But this goes for just not within the peace and security sector, but everywhere.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The, that whatever you do is finite.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It's not sort of open ended and never ending.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so I think it's very important that the accountabilities are set in to have an exit strategy, to have a review structure and the accountability structure to see if things are being met and when you sort of make a plan to end it.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I always tell people that in my UN career I really felt that I was one of the most fortunate UN officials because what I, you know, and a ceremony that I was part of remains, you know, ingrained in me.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: When we lowered the flag of the UN and we raised the flag of Timor Leste and handed over the responsibility, closed the mission and handed over the responsibility of the police to the Timorese authorities.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And the UN was able to say, you know, we've closed our mission successfully.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That rarely happens in the un.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So I feel very privileged that I was part of that.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But I think it can.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So, you know, I just want to close by saying that some of these things, I mean, people have spoken about it.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think people can ask more questions if they want, but I think there's quite a bit of experience, quite a bit of groundbreaking work that has been done.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The key is how we can get back to some good practices that we had that brought the system together, that recognized where expertise was and matched the resources to where the expertise could best deliver on the ground.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And finally to realize when it's time to say, you know, we need to leave.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you very much.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you very much, Ms. Hack, and not only for your presentation today, but for your decades of excellent service to this organization.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I'll now open the floor for any questions from delegations on this technical briefing.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Delegations are reminded that this technical briefing is to be followed by informal consultations at which there will be an opportunity for delegations to deliver statements.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: As we have been asked by you to be mindful of the overlap with meetings of the main committees, please don't make statements today.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Time limits for your questions and comments to the panelists will therefore be limited.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We are asking you to keep within a minute and a half.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I will now give the floor to Costa Rica, to be followed by China.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Good afternoon.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I would like first to thank the.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Co facilitators for organizing this session on mandate implementation and to the speakers for their valuable insights.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Christian, allow me to recognize your leadership.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: On a number of important initiatives.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Their implementation has made this organization stronger.

text: Taking into account the information provided and the content of the ESG report, my delegation wishes to formulate the following questions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In this Recommendation, in paragraph 52.2, the Secretary General suggests there is need to allow UN system entities greater flexibility to resources quickly with reasonable justification, including to protect essential country level delivery from funding cuts.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And Ms. Hug, the examples that you gave really just gave us a good sense and a good feel of what can go wrong or right at the at a country level.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Coming to the report of the sg, we support the proposed solutions for shorter reports, combining reports on similar issues and introducing different formats to address proliferation of meetings and reports.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But we have some questions and I think Mexico and others have asked the same questions as to who will prioritize and streamline requests in mandates for reports and meetings.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Will this task be allocated to the Secretariat and what objective criteria will be used to make this determination of prioritizing and streamlining and maybe should this has not been dealt with at the very beginning during the process of mandate design.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Then on the matter of inadequate delivery, management and coordination we do agree that and support the need to strengthen internal strategic oversight and for mandate citations in programs and budget.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But when we looked at the examples that have been given system wide coordination platforms, all the mechanisms that are in there in the report are internal and we are wondering if it will not save the system for coordination and avoidance of duplication to also make use of other independent units that we already have in the system like the Joint Inspection Unit or the Member State oversight body such as the Committee for Program and Coordination, the cpc.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So looking at independent bodies as part of that system wide thing, then on the misaligned funding modalities that entrenches fragmentation, one of the in the report itself, one of the recommendation there was that the outcome of UNAD pillar 3 is going to assist and we fully agree with that and therefore say we need to look at how we deal with that pillar three carefully because then it's going to help us in dealing with this particular challenge of misaligned finding modalities that entrenches fragmentation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Then lastly, Resolution 79327 on the revitalization of the GA, the work of the GA was mentioned a couple of times and it had a whole section on working methods and some of the recommendations that are there in the report, some of the issues that have been raised are also addressed in that resolution.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So we are wondering if maybe that can be lifted and can be demonstrated how do we further integrate again so that you don't you know that resolution is nowhere there and this UNAIDS over here, how do we integrate and show interconnectedness between the outcomes of that resolution and what we are trying to do here?

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: My question is, to what extent are these reports almost identical?

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In other words, if a report is produced with very little substantial changes or modifications, you know, there must be a way of measuring that.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So if it's largely identical, how many percentage of that 60% of reports that recur?

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I mean, if some estimation of that I think will be useful for us to give a sense as to whether we need an annual update that is largely identical.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So that's where we can go into differentiated formats.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Maybe a two page executive summary update of a previous annual report.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So that's the first set of question.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Second question relates to a request for a report.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: How many instances are there or how often is it the case that a request for report leads to a duplication of reports within the UN system?

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So we request the SG for a report, but that could also prompt a series of agencies to also produce their own report.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And that I think is not a very helpful situation because when we make a request to the sg, we want to see a coherent coordinated report from the UN system, not a series of reports.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And but I want to get some data as to whether this is a big issue of duplication or multiplicity of reports on a specific question when there is a request.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think if some data can be shared with us that would be useful.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Then the third question comment relates to the question of issue of downloaded reports.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I mean there were some statistics about, you know, some that are downloaded more than others.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Yes, I agree that more downloads does not make it more important an issue.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But I think still some data will be useful for me and my delegation to know what are the thematic issues on which there's greater downloading as opposed to other issues.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Because if a report is not downloaded very often, not that we do away with the report, but we need to examine why are those requests being made, say for an important issue but nobody's reading them, then something's wrong with us.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: If we are producing reports that are important and no one's reading them, I mean that's a serious issue that we need to collectively address.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But I think as a starting point we need also some data we could use.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I guess the final point I want to make is more an observation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Very good to see you Martin.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think very interesting presentation that you made.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think this is an issue that I think we have discussed for some time.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The only glimmer of hope I sense is that with AI as a tool, hopefully we know what we know and hopefully we know where to look for what we do not know.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But AI is not the solution in its entirety, but it can be a very important tool.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So that gives me some hope.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But my question though is to what extent is the UN designed to utilize AI as a tool for information or knowledge management as you put it?

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I mean this is a large question, but the question is what do we need to do as the UN to make it future ready that's a very broad question for reflection.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you very much to the co chairs and all the panelists.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank the distinguished representative of Singapore.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Give the floor now to Argentina and then to close us out, the United States.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you, Ambassador.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you to all the panelists.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I have one specific question and it's about one of the proposed solutions that the reports provide regarding I would say the fragmentation or duplication and it's number two when it says ensure UN entities review mandate citations in their programs and budgets so that entities only cite mandates for which they have demonstrable comparative advantage.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So maybe if in a later stage chair, we could have maybe more insights on how those manned citations are done within the Secretary, but also the role of Member states.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I know that the CPC might have a role to play there, but maybe there are other instances where we can address this issue more in deep and maybe the answers will help us to have a also proposal for next meeting.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank the representative of Argentina.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I give the floor now to the representative of the United States.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thanks so much, Ambassador. And I realize I'm last and came.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In late, so I'll try to be.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Quick, but I wanted to make a connection to something that we were speaking about in the last session when we were looking at mandate creation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I think much of the discussion on reports sort of bridges both that discussion and this discussion.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: One caveat.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think at times the metric of how often a report gets downloaded can be a bit misleading because there are a number of very technical meetings, often with a small number of delegates who need that report to inform their deliberations.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: For example, I am going to guess that very few Fifth Committee reports get read outside of the Fifth Committee, and yet they're essential to to the work of the fifth committee.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So the downloading of 2,000 reports as a metric might be a misnomer, but I do think the quality of the reports is critical and I want to compliment the Executive Office of the Secretary General for the quality of the reports that have been provided to us on UN80.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think both the analysis, but even more importantly the way that data is presented, the use of visuals, tables, graphs that I think are light years above the sort of standard quality of information presentation that we receive in most UN reports.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And my question then, and this is not something that needs to be answered now by any means, but what is the obstacle to bringing the quality of data presentation that that we're Getting in the UN 80 reports to all of the rest of reports that we use across the various committees and bodies of the un.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thanks.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank the representative of the United States.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That brings us to the last speaker for today.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In light of the time we had promised to keep these tight, we will provide written answers in as much as we can do so ahead of the consultations which will take place on the 14th of November.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And we look forward to seeing you all there.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you for your presence today.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you to our briefers, our panelists, and to all of you at the the Secretariat team for providing the space as well.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you so much.

session_title: Mandate Implementation briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The meeting is adjourned.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Good morning.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Good morning, colleagues.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: May I invite you to take your seats?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Good morning.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I call to order the informal meeting of the Working Group for consultations on the matter of mandate implementation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: On behalf of Ambassador Schwarger, I warmly welcome all of you to today's consultations on mandate implementation under the ongoing UNAT review process.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We begin by recognizing the presence of Mr. Guy Ryder, under Secretary General for Policy and chair of the UN 80 task force his Excellency Christian Venavesso, Permanent representative of Liechtenstein Mr. Martin Kimani, President and Chief Executive Officer of the African center and former Permanent Representative of Kenya and who is joining us virtually along with Mr. Meera Haq, former United Nations Under Secretary General for the Department of Field Support, former co Chair of the High Level Independent Panel on Peace Operations and former Secretary General Special Representative for Timor Lest and Head of the United Nations Integrated Mission in East Timor.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The objective of this session is to collectively reflect on the insights and recommendations emerging from the Mandate implementation briefing on 30 October and to identify concrete next step that can enhance efficiency, transparency and accountability in how mandates are implemented across the United nations system.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We welcome views on the recommendations made on mandate implementation in the Secretary General's report, as well as any additional proposals Working Group members may wish to put forward themselves.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We aim to foster a shared understanding of the challenges and opportunities inherent in mandate implementation, strengthen coordination among entities and ensure that our collective efforts are guided by the principles of effectiveness, inclusivity and results oriented delivery in support of the organization's overarching goals.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In this vein, we wish to reassure Member States that we have taken careful note of the valuable recommendations provided to the Working Group thus far.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We reiterate the importance of maintaining a collaborative and inclusive approach with the full engagement of all Member States to ensure a process that is both effective and transparent.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Our shared objective remains to achieve the highest possible level of ambition.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: By the conclusion of this exercise, we aim to inspire fresh, pragmatic and innovative thinking that strengthens the culture of mandate design and implementation across the United nations system.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: As we continue our engagement in this discovery phase, we hope to deepen our collective understanding of mandates, guided by empirical evidence, analytical insights and lessons drawn from best practices across the United nations system.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: There appear to be some emerging areas of common interest that we have discerned from the consultations and discussions to date.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It is our intention to elaborate on those when we provide our Interim report to you on December 11th and in our subsequent communications to you ahead of our work on the Production phase, which will begin in Mid January.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We look forward to hearing more from you today.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: As we look at mandate implementation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Today, Working Group members will first hear responses to questions posed at the Mandate implementation briefing on 30 October.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: As you're aware, answers provided by the Secretariat were shared under cover of a letter from the co chairs on the 12th of November and these will also be made available on the UN80 Initiative website.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Additionally, as advised in that letter, Working Group members will have the opportunity today to express their their views on mandate implementation and we look forward to hearing your ideas and proposals.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We invite you please to submit your interventions as well as any additional inputs by uploading these to the Edelegate portal, as well as sending these to us in writing via our email address@unity mandates.co chairs Gmail.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: As expressed in our last meeting, we intend to compile and publish the contributions of Working Group members on the UNAT Initiative website unless otherwise indicated by you.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Your inputs will contribute to building a comprehensive picture of how we might better tackle mandates in the future.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I now pass the floor to my co Chair, Ambassador Schwalgo.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Good morning, everybody.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Before we turn to the questions posed to the briefers, we just wanted to take this opportunity to share that as Co Chairs, we have recently held engagements with the presidents of the Boards and leadership teams of several UN funds, programs and agencies to deepen our understanding of how the issue of mandate creation, implementation and review is being considered in their organisations and what this could mean for the Working Groups, development, deliberations and approach going forward.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We have also been meeting with the Chairs of the Main Committees and the co facilitators of the GA revitalization process to ensure that we understand their operating context and any implications for this Working Group.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We also wish to inform members of the Working Group that we, as Co Chairs, will hold a meeting on 19 November in coordination with the Executive Office of the Secretary General, to hear directly from UN system entities on their experiences with mandate implementation and to exchange views on how the review can be made more meaningful and impactful.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In particular, we will focus on strengthening UN system engagement and exploring how analytical work can best support the deliberations of this Working Group.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We also plan to travel to Geneva and Vienna in early January to undertake further consultations with Member States and UN system entities there.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So it is now my honour to offer the floor to our briefers, who will provide additional answers to Questions posed at the 30 October briefing on Mandate implementation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: First, I give the floor to Mr. Guy Ryder, under Secretary General, for Policy to further elaborate on the answers provided to Member States in the form of visual illustrations and follow up to the many questions raised during the recent briefing on mandate implementation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Floor is yours.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In the first instance, Ambassador Schwalger, Ambassador Wallace, thank you for this opportunity to be one of the briefers in today's session of the Working Group.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And more than that, thank you for the extraordinary leadership you're providing in the work of the Working Group.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And I think the attendance in the room this morning is evidence of the very strong engagement of Member States in the important work you are carrying out.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Now.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Let me say that it is important that we do continue to work together on the discussion of the overall life cycle approach to mandates that we are basing our work upon.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Focusing today, of course, most particularly on the delivery stage of the life cycle.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Do I have graphics on the screen?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I do.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Can I give you some perhaps context to the discussion today?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: As has been mentioned by Ambassador Wallace, we shared some written responses to the questions raised at the session of 30th of October.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: You have received them and I don't think it would be a useful use of your time to repeat what is in those responses.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So instead I can perhaps use this time to highlight what seemed to us to be some of the key points that we shared and provide just a little bit of context in some areas that may be of relevance.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I want to begin by underlining why the work that is being done here is so critically important, why it is essential that we streamline and strengthen the UN system's mandate delivery.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: If we take a look at our resource situation, you look at the graphic ahead of us.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It's not a new graphic.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: You can see that we are projecting that resources across the entirety of of the United nations systems might well shrink by as much as 25% in 2026 next year compared to the levels of 2024.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And I think that provides a very clear message to us that we simply must focus on optimizing processes, eliminating duplications, if we are to continue to serve the people who need our assistance most.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Let me then turn to some more specific aspects in relation to mandate delivery, which is the focus of today's session.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The first point that I could perhaps make relates to reports.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Let me again draw your attention to two statistics, two numbers that we've already shared, but is perhaps worth lingering on again.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: If you look at this graphic, you will see that a total of 66% of reports cover recurring topics.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Topics have come on, come back again and again, and 46% of our reports are produced either annually or more frequently than annually.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So if you look at the red boxes here, you will see that those two boxes up to 46%, sort of.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In very plain terms, this means that we are spending considerable time and resources writing reports on the same or similar issues in successive years.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And of course, in many cases, this is absolutely necessary and appropriate.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We understand that annual updates are often appropriate and necessary, but that does not or should not disguise the possibility that there may be opportunities to optimize the format, the length or the periodicity of certain reports.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I cannot claim that the statistics before you are conclusive, but they are certainly suggestive.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: On the other hand, and in some instances, to preserve both Member States bandwidth and respect, that and the Secretariat's capacity, it might be worth considering whether some reports could shift to a biannual or even longer cycle of publication.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: That's reports.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Let's move on to funding issues.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Colleagues, on funding, the graphic before you shows that the UN system's work relies on very heavily on voluntary contributions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Roughly 80% of our total resources are from voluntary contributions, and therefore only 20 are derived from assessed funding of any kind.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: This also shows that the UN Secretariat accounts for only a relatively small share of overall system resources.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Most UN system funding, and therefore most delivery, takes place outside the Secretariat across funds, programs and specialized agencies.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And this level of voluntary funding dependence means that the way that voluntary funding is provided its predictability, its flexibility, or its earmarking has a major impact on how effectively we can deliver on the mandates that you hand to us.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The other dimension of this consideration concerns the size of the grant packages, the funding packages that we get.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I think it is noteworthy that 63% of our grants are for amounts below $1 million.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: This funding comes in small packages.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: A large share of our funding is delivered in these many small transactions, and each of these naturally carries with it its own administrative requirements.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And inevitably, the consequence is of a high administrative cost per individual grant compared with larger grants, consolidated contributions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: This is a situation which raises the level of overhead costs.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In addition, in past years there has been declining support for pooled funds.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Less than 10% of voluntary funding came through pooled funds in development and humanitarian action.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And that is far below the target established in the Funding Compact, which was a target of 30%.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The target was 30%.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The reality is 10%.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And here too is an area where it would be extremely valuable if this Working group could take a closer look at remedial action.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: May I?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Also, without going beyond that, I'm conscious of the need not to do so beyond the boundaries of the work of of this Working Group.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Draw your attention to proposals which are included in Work Stream 3, the report on Workstream 3 that was published by the Secretary General shortly before High Level Week, which relate to this topic.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: For your reference, they are in paragraphs 97 to 101 of the Secretary General's Report on Workstream 3. I think you will notice from this that there is a clear area this is a clear area where Work Streams two and three do converge.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In our Work Stream two report, we have identified specific challenges to mandate delivery, and in Work Stream 3, we try to identify specific avenues to address the challenges in terms of our structures and our programs.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In the meeting on the 30th of October, several of you asked how we can address issues of fragmentation in our delivery.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Issues of fragmentation and duplication have been recurring issues in our Work Stream 3 report.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: To reference it again, we provided some avenues to address fragmentation, such as scaling up common services, creating a single entry point for macroeconomic analysis, and establishing joint knowledge hubs.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: But generally speaking, we need to assess where different UN entities have a comparative advantage and how they can work together to leverage those comparative advantages to best effect.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And one way to approach that challenge is to look at what particular function an entity fulfills.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In the graphic before you, we list some of the big categories of function, normative support, policy advice, data and statistics, capacity building, convening, service delivery and support, and other functions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: What we are trying to get to through this lens is where each part of the UN system can deliver on the aspect of a mandate that it is best equipped to handle with clear divisions of labor, which would help to eliminate dangers of duplication.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: If that sounds rather abstract, let me just try to give an example to illustrate the point.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It's an example taken simply because it does illustrate the point, rather than for any other reason, the issue of global vaccination program.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So the WHO provides the normative and technical guidance and policy advice, setting the global standards for childhood vaccinations, and working with governments on how to translate global vaccination goals, international public health plans.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: That's one function.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Gavi, not strictly part of the UN system, supports the funding function, and UNICEF in turn focuses on support functions such as procurement to vaccine delivery on the ground, working with your national health authorities to reach families and children to deliver the vaccinations.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And here you see what might at first sight look like duplication is in fact a very efficient and complementary division along functional complementary functional lines.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In this way, UN entities play Complementary, not duplicative, roles, ensuring that together we can deliver the greatest possible impact.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So, co chairs, those were some of the additional clarifications that I wanted to share.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I hope they're helpful to you and of course I look forward to listening to your statements and to our continued conversations around the UN systems Mandate delivery.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Thank you very much.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Very helpful.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Under Secretary General Ryder, I now give the floor to His Excellency Christian Venavesa, Permanent Representative of Liechtenstein.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We're particularly interested in hearing from you on which measures you would prioritise to improve mandate impact and any thoughts you might have on reporting, given that came up very frequently and the mandate implementation briefing and of course, any of the other questions that were posed.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The floor is yours.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Great. Thank you so much.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It's very good to be back.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And again, big thanks to you for steering this process in such a structured and transparent way.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I think people know that the questions asked were mostly asked to the Secretariat and that will not take up that much time for that reason.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And you've already heard extremely helpful replies from Guy Ryder and I will focus on on what Carolyn has just mentioned.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In particular, measures to improve impact and efficiency across the system.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: As far as mandates, as you know from my briefing, I strongly believe that we should put more efforts into crafting our mandates very carefully.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And I think that would be my biggest wish and my most important suggestion.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So there has to be consultation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: There have to be consultations, not just among ourselves states, but also with the relevant parts of the Secretariat, which honestly will help us to just understand what we are doing and what we are proposing.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And in particular, if we are proposing something that is perhaps already done or in part already done.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So we do believe that a consultation on substance, but also on procedure and on whether something is legally sound is extremely important to craft good mandates and to also have an understanding of what the implementation of a mandate will cost.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So we believe every resolution should be costed and that we should, before making a decision on how we express ourselves on a proposed new mandate, that we know the financial aspect of a decision.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Linked to this is the question of reporting that you have also flagged.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Carolyn, as you know, I think the first question for us should be do we need a report?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Because we do not believe that every resolution does need a report.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The report can be extremely important and can be big value added.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: But that is not the case always.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And right now, I think mentally we are in a sort of space of automaticity.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: You have a resolution, so you need an SG report.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So I think we need to rethink that and look at this, at this differently.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Then also think about, well, perhaps it's good to have a report at the beginning to frame a conversation and to give us a real basis to take a topic forward.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: But maybe as we move ahead in the delivery of a mandate, and Guy has made it very clear in his comments how many reports are on regularly recurring topics and maybe the moment will come where the membership has sufficient information or is sufficiently served with being provided additional information and things that have changed.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: There are in fact reports that consist mainly of submissions by Member States.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: These reports tend to be extremely duplicative and repetitive.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Sometimes they're very lengthy.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: These are probably reports, we don't need it all anymore.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: But again, it should be something that we look at as proponents of mandates, but also as those who are consulted and as part of the negotiations.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The periodicity is also something that is best looked at at the very beginning if you propose a new mandate.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I think, again, this sort of reflex to say we do this every year because I think it's important is not necessarily, I mean, I don't think that is actually accurate.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: I think it can have an extremely important mandate that is, that is discussed only three or five years.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And that is something we should think about when we, when we draft our mandates.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And this is linked also a little bit on impact, but also on the question, what are we doing here?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Is this forward looking, is this backward looking?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So certainly we would hope that we will have a much better toolbox for ourselves as we move ahead in our work, as we move forward, as we start crafting new mandates, as of course we will and as we have to, and that we implement the measures that are being discussed here, but that will also allow us to do it with already existing mandates because they typically come back.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So if we embrace a new way of doing this and if we embrace new best practices, of course that can then be applied also, also to mandates as they, as they come back and as we resubmit or renew them.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So that is probably it for me.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And thanks for having me.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It's a great pleasure to offer my comments.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: That's really helpful as well.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We now give the floor to Mr. Martin Kamani, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Africa center and former Permanent Representative of Kenya, to respond to the question posed to him during the briefing on mandate implementation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And for your memory, that question read, to what extent, extent can the UN utilize AI for information or knowledge management and what is needed to become future ready?

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And Martin of course, you're very welcome to share any brief reactions to any of the other questions posed as well.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Floor is yours.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Thank you very much.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: VR and Board Chairs, thank you for inviting me once again to deliberate with you on this important topic for this important working group.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: You asked to what extent the UN can utilize AI for information and knowledge management and what is needed for the organization to become future ready, and I will draw on the remarks that I shared on 30 October which outlined the UN structural knowledge problem and the cost it imposes on implementation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: As I briefed you then, the UN is rich in knowledge, yet staff and delegations rarely have that knowledge at the moment of decision.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: This weakens implementation, slows crisis response, and forces the system to relearn what it already knows.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: AI cannot replace political judgment, conflict, understanding or diplomacy, but it can remove the friction that consumes staff time and attention.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And this is where the opportunity lies.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: A significant share of UN work is mechanical and rule based.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Administrative processing, financial workflows, indicator management, translation support, document retrieval, data cleaning, structured summaries and reference preparation.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: These processes can be automated quite safely.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: AI can also assemble inputs for higher level analysis.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It can retrieve resolutions, extract factual timelines, surface comparable cases and collate open source reporting.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: These are repeatable tasks that do not require political sensitivity.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: In fact, when Kenya was in the Security Council, we had a machine reading team in Nairobi that was doing just that, open source work that helped us a great deal in working on files where Kenya did not have a credible intelligence gathering system.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Automation in these areas expands the usable bandwidth of staff who must apply judgment.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: It reduces the administrative burden that currently constrains the UN's ability to deliver and takes up so much of the financial resources.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The Political Call the UN must remain human.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Drafting the Secretary General's reports, the political analysis, the mandate interpretation that Christian was talking about, the conflict assessment, early warning, judgment negotiations, mapping of red lines, the way narratives are framed in complex and crisis situations.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: These depend on contextual understanding and sensitivity to member state positions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: They require tacit knowledge acquired through experience and AI cannot perform these functions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So the aim I was talking about last time, and as I repeat now, is reinforcement of political work, not its substitution.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Automation strengthens the UN core mandate in three ways.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: First, deeper analysis.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Analysts gain more time for political consultation, reading and scenario testing when no longer required to reconstruct timelines or search for documents.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Early warning improves when staff focus on incentives, power dynamics and emerging risks.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Second, faster and clearer decisions.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Decision cycles accelerate when automated systems produce timelines, comparable cases, legal references, etc. Thirdly, diplomacy strengthens, negotiation improves when envoys have more time for bilateral consultations and political outreach.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: Automated retrieval, past commitments, voting patterns and red lines frees you to have the energy to shape outcomes.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: And especially this point is relevant to the smallest missions that struggle with the present workload.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: So automation protects the space for human political judgment and therefore increases both delegations and Secretariat's capacity without expanding headcount.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: We also have to respond to the new cyber threat environment.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: The AI enabled cyber espionage campaign that was documented by Anthropic, which runs Claude AI.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: If you use it.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
text: This mid September, just a few weeks ago, marked a turning point.

session_title: Mandate Implementation consultations - Statements from members of the working group  Part 1
