text: And I think one way of looking at this review phase of the cycle is to see it as a sort of a steering operation where member states have the opportunity to set the forward trajectory of the organization and its activities.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And if we're able to do that well, the entire mandate cycle can stay on course, moving us where we want to get to towards greater positive impact.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And alternatively, when it's not done so well, I think we can all see that there is a danger that the system can enter into a sort of drift, and we want to avoid that.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, as we see it, for a mandate review process to work optimally, two conditions reflected in the graphic before you would need to be met.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Firstly, Member States would need to have available to them a review process that allows them to steer strategically, not simply automatically to repeat discussions year after year as a sort of a. A default position.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But that's only one half of the story.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The other half is that the UN system, our responsibility is to provide information that you need to assess the work that we have undertaken.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: You need to have access to clear plans, clear results, and a presentation of the links between resource utilization and outcomes obtained.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So we believe these two components would be integral to a successful review phase.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, perhaps I can go through each of these components in turn, beginning with the Member State review process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, the question we might ask is what are the means at the disposal of Member States to provide the type of steer that the organization requires?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Obviously, the resolutions that you adopt are the most important and obvious instrument at your disposal.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But there is more than that because you shape the organization's direction also by deciding what goes on the agenda, how often issues come back for discussion, the kinds of reports that you want and how frequently you want them.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And then all of this comes on top of the resolutions that you ultimately adopt.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: All of this indicates that you Member States are in the pilot seat throughout this entire process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: You set the course and the UN system must follow your direction and do it to its best abilities.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, in the mandates report, we identified initially the issue of frequently recurring business with limited changes to mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That's in quotes.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Frequently recurring business with limited changes to mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And some of the statistics that we presented in the report, I think are quite suggestive.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In 2024, the General assembly discussed about 370 agenda items and sub items.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And of these, about 60%.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Two hundred and fifteen are discussed every year.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thirty percent of the issues discussed have been considered since 1990, and 55% of recurring resolutions have been very similar to the ones adopted in previous years, meaning at least 80% of the text is identical, the same word for word.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And these numbers, as I've said, are suggestive that in certain aspects, the steering process that I'VE talked to might simply be operating by autopilot now.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Currently, as I've indicated, many agenda items come back year after year and there may be reason for that.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I don't think it is self evident that this is inappropriate, particularly for entity specific or operational mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It may be that this makes perfect sense, but perhaps for larger system wide transformative agenda, the ones where change takes time, reviewing them less frequently but perhaps with more time and attention could be more useful.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It could give space for meaningful progress over time and means that when negotiations do happen there is a real addition of value.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: As has been stressed by many of you in previous meetings in this working group, and I recall Ambassador Wray's parting intervention last time, these processes are not set in stone, they are amenable to change.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The periodicity of considering agenda items, requesting reports and adopting resolutions can, if you so decide, all be adapted so that issues stay on the radar but recur at the most appropriate and productive intervals possible.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In the report we also underlined that Member States could decide to undertake collective assessments of mandates, addressing related issues rather than addressing mandates one by one.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now these kinds of collective reviews, if I could call them those, they do happen, but they are the exception rather than the rule.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: One example of a collective review is the revitalization of the General assembly, which you are all familiar with.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Another is the quadriennnual Comprehensive Policy Review, the QCPR process, which takes a strategic system wide view of the entirety of the UN development system.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And as you are aware, the QCPR runs on a four year cycle, setting expectations for the entire UN development system, not just entity by entity or individual issue by issue.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And this longer cycle creates a degree of space for real delivery, for learning, and for adjusting course in ways which are meaningful and consequential.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: There are other examples, but perhaps a QCPR approach is one which is instructive for other pillars as well.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: A further issue that we highlighted in the report is that most mandates do not include review mechanisms in them, and as you can see from this straightforward slide, around 86% of mandates lack any review mechanisms and this means that renewal can become the default setting even when circumstances may have changed.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Of the 14% of UN mandates which do include review clauses, it's interesting to note that most are resolutions adopted by the Security Council and the Human Rights Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: They tend to relate to peace operations, fact finding missions or commissions of inquiry or sanctions measures.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I think you will hear more about these from my colleagues with us today in their presentations in the Development Pillar.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: One example where we have a Built in process and timeline is Resolution 71 of 2015, the one that adopted the Sustainable Development Goals.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That resolution sets the SDG horizon for 2030, after which member States will review the progress made and determine next steps, as was indeed already the case after the deadline set for the Millennium Development Goals.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So when it matters, clearly these things can be done.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: A more recent example, one which might be fresh in the memory of many of us, is General assembly resolution 79325 on the establishment and functioning of the independent Artificial Intelligence Panel.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That resolution includes a review mechanism and timeline, and I quote, the continuation of the terms of reference of the Panel and the dialogue may be considered by the General assembly during the review of the Global Digital compact at its 82nd session.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: These are examples of resolutions which do have built in review mechanisms and we might learn from them.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In these cases, the predictability of the review process and timeline may be helpful in ensuring that structured discussions among Member States are prioritized, and this in itself can lead to better outcomes.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, having said all of that in respect of Member States, let me recall the role of the the system itself, the UN system, in this process, the second component that I mentioned at the outset, and recall the four potential solutions in this regard that were included in the Secretary General's report.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I would recall that these are the manner in which Member States could seek to systematize review practices across mandating bodies, make review clauses the norm, review and steer impact more collectively, meaning at the level of systems development, humanitarian peace and security, or the human rights pillar and streamline agenda to spend less time repeating discussions and more time steering strategically.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Sorry, that part still belongs to the Member States component.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I'm now moving on to the UN System component Excellency's colleagues.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: As it regards the UN System side, our role is to provide inputs to enable your review to operate optimally.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: As I've said, for reviews to work well, the system must provide a clear picture on how mandates translate into results.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And here there are four things we need to pay attention to.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We need a roadmap, a strategic plan on what goals any entity is pursuing long term.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We need a results chain, a framework linking resources to activities, outputs and outcomes.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: A budget that shows value organized around results, not just cost categories in a more administrative manner.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And we need strong communication reports that show our stakeholders how our work is making a difference.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Today, as our report reflects, the challenge is that these plans, these results change.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: These budgets often look different in different parts of the UN system.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Some entities have strategic plans, others do not.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Some have Integrated results and resource frameworks, but many don't.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And how we measure results differs across UN entities.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Reporting and planning tools are inconsistent.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The consequence of all of this is that it makes it hard for you, our Member States, to judge system wide performance or compare the impact of the work of different entities and from this to draw appropriate conclusions.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So that is why we point to one simple but critical potential solution to these challenges in the Secretary General's report.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And that is to strengthen and harmonize management for results mechanisms across the UN system, including how results are measured and how they are communicated.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Breaking that down in concrete terms, that means that every major entity should have, firstly, a multi year strategic plan, secondly, an integrated results and resource framework based on a system wide standard, and thirdly, a budget that is organized around results, not just categories like staff and operations, administrative cost categories.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And when results chains are completed are complete.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Excuse me.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And when budgets show how they contribute to outcomes, this enables a lot of things to happen.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It enables you to have a system wide view of impact and how it is obtained, to see how different entities contribute to shared outcomes, this thorny issue of overlap and duplication, to see whether resources are aligned with results and to see where adjustments might be needed.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Co Chairs, Dear participants, let me draw to a conclusion by clarifying that this type of mandate review is not simply about adding another layer of bureaucracy or process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It can be a tool for you to ensure that the UN system is and remains focused, coherent, effective and accountable.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: With better designed review cycles and stronger performance information, we can make our mandate delivery more strategic and above all, more impactful.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Ultimately then, this is not about process, it's about people.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It's about the 8 billion people the UN system connects to shared goals.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It's about the 400 million people whose lives the UN helps improve on the ground, most of them in least developed countries.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So I hope that we can work together through this working group to deliver better for the people who depend on us.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I thank you once again for this opportunity and look forward to your comments and questions.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you, Jess. Thank you, Guy. Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I now give the floor to Mr. Lok Bahadur Tafa, Permanent Representative of Nepal to the United nations and President of the Economic and Social Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you, distinguished Co Chairs, Excellencies, distinguished delegations.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you Co Chairs for inviting me today to join you.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It is always a pleasure to talk about the ECOSOCS mandate, which is firmly rooted in the Charter entrusting the Council with responsibilities to promote international cooperations on economic, social, cultural, educational, health and related issues.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: ECOSOC serves as a platform for dialogue and policymaking, coordinating the UN development systems and engaging diverse stakeholders.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: ECOSOCS approaches the reviews stakeholders stage of the mandate life cycle through a range of legislative and oversight functions derived from the UN Charter GA resolutions and outcomes of the UN conferences and summits.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Since the adoptions of the 2030 Agenda, ECOSOC has focused on coherence across the UN systems to support member states in meeting the global commitments.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The High Level Political Forum, convened annually under its auspices, is the central platform to review SDG progress, share lessons and adopt our ministerial declarations.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Beyond the hlpf, ECOSOC holds annual forums on financing for development, partnerships, youth and science and technology and innovations, adopting resolutions and recommendations across its program of work.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It also responds to urgent global issues through special meetings that inform its broader sessions.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Excellencies Viewing its own annual work program, the Council is also interested to oversee the work of five regional Commissions, eight functional Commissions, nine Export Committees, two Standing Committees, and a range of other bodies that report to it.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: These subsidiary bodies address a wide range of sustainable development issues, from statistics and crime prevention to science and technology, forest population, gender equality, indigenous peoples issues, as well as the needs of the LECs.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: They regularly report on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The Council periodically reviews their work on the basis of the recommendations contained in the reports of the subsidiary bodies as well as provides guidance based on current trends and needs on their future work.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: For instance, during its 2025 sessions, Ecosoc adopted 35 resolutions, signed 45 decisions, not including those related to elections.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The Council discharges its charter mandated coordination functions by reviewing the work undertaken by the UN systems on the sustainable development issues across the economic, social, health and related fields, with a view to promoting coordinated actions and advancing long term solutions.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Excellencies in recent years there have been efforts to streamline mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The ECOSOC Vice President, Costa rica at the 2025 session issued a Call to Action for the Humanitarian affairs segment in state of negotiating a resolution.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Streamlining mandates also includes avoiding the introduction of new mandates unless accompanied by commensurate resources or by the clear adjustment or conclusion of existing overlapping obligations.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: There are also lessons learned from the recent experiences, particularly regarding the process of adoption of the Ministerial Declaration at both HLPF and Ecosoc.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The 2024 Ministerial Declaration illustrated challenges due to procedural arrangements and the potential conflicts caused by the different voting rights at the ECOSOC and the hlpf.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Member States may wish to address these situations during the forthcoming GA review of ECOSOC and the HLPF Excellencies The General assembly periodically reviews ECOSOC work and the provisions governing the HLPF in its resolutions 78285 the General assembly agreed to fully review at its 80th sessions the arrangement of the ecosocial and the HLPF.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: These reviews will be conducted jointly.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Building on the lesson learned to ensure alignment with the broader 2030 Agenda follow up processes following GA Resolution 75 290A ECOSOC launched an internal review of its subsidiary bodies in 2022 facilitated by the Council Vice President.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The process included assessment and recommendations by the Bureau of ecosoc Functional Commissions and expert bodies and informal consultations among Member States.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: This process resulted in ECOSOC Decisions 2022334 inviting implementations of the recommendations contained in the Vice President's summary.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Furthermore, a number of ECOSUC functional commissions also conduct periodic reviews of their own working methods.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The next review of ECOSAC subsidiary bodies initially mandated for 2026 is proposed to be postponed to 2027 to allow the process to be informed by the outcomes of the GA review process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In line with the fact of the future, ECOSHOCK launched an intergovernmental process in 2025 to explore option to revitalize the CSW Co facilitated by Ireland and St. Kitts and Navies.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The process concluded with the adoption of ECOSOC resolutions on revitalizations of the CSW reaffirming CSW's role in follow up to the Fourth World Conference on Women and its outcome.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The efforts have also been made to foster more effective complementarity between the General assembly and ecosac with the QCPR as an example of the two bodies identifying complementary rules namely of policymaking one for the GA every four years and the annual oversight of implementation and guidance by Member States to the UN Development Systems and Funding Compact ousted under ECOSOC in its Operational Activities for Development segment.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Regular dialogue between the President of the GA and ECOSOC help ensure coherence including monthly meetings and annual joint meetings to identify shared and important issues of relevance to Member States Excellencies regarding the voluntary national reviews.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The 2030 Agenda encourages member States to undertake regular and inclusive reviews of progress at national and sub national levels.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: These reviews are intended to be voluntary and country driven by presented at the HLPF under the auspices of ECOSA.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Since 2015, 402 PNRs have been presented by 190 countries and the European Union with 148 countries submitting two or more reviews.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The Resolution 75-190B suggested improvements the BNRs encouraging countries to highlight challenges, gaps and next steps to accelerate the implementation of the SDG and to conduct a BNR once the four year cycle of the hlpf.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Nonetheless, certain challenges in the BNR process continue to be observed and addressing them could further strengthen the mechanisms, effectiveness and impact Excellencies.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Integrated nature of the 2030 agenda requires close cooperations across intergovernmental bodies.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The upcoming ECOSOC and HLPF review by the GA is an opportunity to reflect on the Council work and enhance the complementarity between ECOSOC and HLPF to ensure that their work is mutually reinforcing and accelerate the 2030 Agenda implementation.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Taken together, the UN 80 initiative, the General assembly review of EcoShock and HLPF at its 80th session and the EcoShock review of its subsidiary machinery create opportunities for Member States to strengthen the functions, coherence and the impact of the ECOSAC and HLPF in advancing the 2030 Agenda and its SDGs.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank you.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank the president of Ecosop.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I now give the floor to Ms. Inga Anderson, executive Director of the United Nations Environment Program.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you very much and good evening from Nairobi, the only global headquarters of the United nations in the Global South.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It's a pleasure and honor to speak here today this evening and we think that this mandate review is very critical and we've engaged very much throughout the process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: UNEP, the United Nations Environment Program, was founded in 1972 in the Stockholm Conference and it really is the place whereby mandate we're supposed to promote international cooperation on the environment, keep the environment under review, which essentially is science, and serve as a focal point for environmental action within the UN system.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so being that pillar of the environment, we are enriched when other agencies take on the environmental issue but but address it through their mandate lens, be it human rights, be it children, be it health, et cetera.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So what some would call decentralization of the environmental mandate to the country, we call it a great strengthening and we need to think about this like you do in the context of your ministries of environment, where of course, whether it's roads or transport or urban or health environment features just as much so for UNEP itself.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Over the years since 1972 we have seen Member States through the UNEP processes give birth to a large number of conventions and two of these, you will know well, are not managed by UNEP or not hosted by UNEP.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That will be climate change and desertification.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But 17 others are indeed hosted by UNEP.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And of course, therefore but of course answerable to the party driven governance process of the COP structure, which you will know very well in 2022 and again in 2024 at the United Nations Environment assembly, discussions were held.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: How can we ensure that the Environmental assembly, the United Nations Environmental assembly, creates a greater degree of synergy without interfering in the sovereign nature, if I can say so, of the multilateral environmental agreements and their cops?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so at this point now in the unea, the United Nations Environment assembly, each assembly has an MEA day, an MEA Week, mea, Multilateral Environment Agreement.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Executive Directors and Presidents come and participate in high level discussions and panels, et cetera.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: There's a tent, because we are a tent city here.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: When we have unea, which the whole week will focus on MEA dialogue precisely to enable a greater synergistic conversation, so to say, then how do we work and how do we maximize the impact of the mandates that are given to us by Member States through the United Nations Environment Assembly?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Well, Member States are about to, in December, at the upcoming UNEA Environment assembly, approve the next four year medium term strategy and the two year program of work.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: This will be decided of course at the conference, but at the Assembly.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But essentially it will deal with the three elements that UNEPT works on.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: If I can summarize very much, climate stability, nature, biodiversity and land and pollution.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And what we then do is we construct a one impact framework that ensures that the whole of UNEP approach, where the different programs and projects that are funded by a variety of sources which are delivering obviously the mandate are then reported on and leads to an organizationally agreed by Member States vision under the medium term strategy.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So the impact framework also rides on a very, very strong measurement framework which shows how the work that we are doing here at UNEP is aligned with the International Agreed Goals, I.e.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: the goals in the Climate Convention, in the Chemical Conventions, in the Biodiversity Convention, et cetera.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so that allows for that.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Even though these multilateral environmental agreements and their COPS take their decisions outside of the UNEA structure, nevertheless, a program that we see Member States approve is underpinning the very commitments that Member States have made in the COP structure.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So therefore, we have an integrated theory of change that link the mandates to measurable outcomes and that ensures that we translate those mandates that have derived from UNEA or indeed from the cops into quantifiable impact and not just sort of activities.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And the targets for these are set on the basis of implementation capacity and budgets, obviously.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so when it comes to resource mobilization, because we only receive around 3% of our monies from the regular budget and the rest we mobilize.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so we seek to do this based on an allocation of all resources.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We have a strategic planning process that is linked with program budgeting.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Our total program in a two year period is just under 3 billion.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The vast amount of this obviously being programmatic.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And we mobilize as if regular budget, but voluntary indicative scale of contribution just usually is around 19 million or so per year.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That helps to pay for the spine of the organization.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So when we seek to then report to Member States, we seek to show progress against agreed indicators which are publicly available.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I should say to ensure that UNEP can be transparent and very much seen that here's what the science says, here's what Member States decided, here's what UNEP is doing.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That model demonstrates very much how the results based evidence informs, performs the mandate review and connects the mandates to the results, to the learning, etc.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We do regular program performance reports to Member States.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We do that on a quarterly basis.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so there's also a learning dimension obviously in that.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So through all of this with a mandate, we take very much, if I can say so, a life cycle approach to the mandate that is given to us, that are given to us by Member States, the strategic guidance, the development, support and implementation.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, since we are supposed to keep the environment under the review and therefore do the science, if I can say so, and you will recall that IPCC was created by a UNEP Governing Council resolution, you will recall that ipbs, a Biodiversity and Land Science Policy Panel, was created by a UNEP Governing Council resolution.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And just recently the Intergovernmental Science Policy Panel on Chemicals, Waste and Pollution Created by UNEA resolution.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That science plus what UNEP Secretariat does itself allows us to do some degree of horizon watching to therefore the Executive Director about nine months or so before the United Nations Environment assembly issue a report to Member States saying these are the areas that are sort of horizon issues where you may wish to.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Well, recognizing that resolutions are a totally sovereign issue pertaining to Member States and prerogative.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Nevertheless, as we are supposed to review the science, we say here are areas that are coming up that are urgent or important or under attended to.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Member States may then decide or not to take inspiration from the Executive Director's report to submit resolutions in that space.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Once resolutions begin to be submitted, we submit a what we call a technical note on each resolution.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: This is a technical note that deals with five issues.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: How is that particular resolution aligned with the existing mandate and a strategy that you are about to approve at the same assembly, what is the relationship to existing mandates either within UNEP or in other fora that is is it duplicative?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In which case we would suggest it's duplicative and therefore you may wish to rethink Third, a legal assessment on the substance and procedural matters.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Fourth, the impact of the proposed draft.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: How would we measure whether we have done the thing that is being proposed?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And fifth, how much is it going to cost?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And so this we make available this Technical Note to Member States well ahead of the United Nations Environment assembly to allow Member States to use this as they would see fit for their consideration and deliberations.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We also allow us assign a technical, technically, scientifically and technical qualified focal point to be available to Member States in each of the resolution discussion meetings and of course we provide oral briefing briefings to Member States on the technical notes to ensure that some of the finer technical and scientific issues are highlighted.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, once a resolution has been adopted, we then support Member States through the implementation tracking portal and reporting portal.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We have established a resolutions portal that is publicly accessible and that monitors and reports on how we're doing on resolution A, B or C. It tracks and outlines the implementation plans for each resolution.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It provides milestones, the results, the availability of resources, the learning, the opportunity and the challenges, the risks and the lessons learned, the partners and so on and so forth.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And because we see of course Member States circulate in and out in terms of our permanent representatives, so we do familiarization sessions with permanent missions with this tracker so that they themselves, when new PRs come in, can follow this through.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And when we have completed a task, and an obvious one would be that we were asked two years ago to help establish the Science Policy Panel on Chemicals, Waste and Pollution and in July of this year this got gaveled and so we therefore have this panel.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So now that resolution can be retired, but when a resolution has been completed, then the monitoring and reporting portal for resolutions will provide a detailed report on the completion of that particular resolution.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now you asked me my final point to reflect on the SG's report on the proposed solutions to improve the mandate review and we support all of the above and then some we think that there's a lot that could be done to follow quicker through, to monitor better, maybe particularly in two areas, to systematize and to reinforce the efforts that are underway to strengthen the mandate review mechanisms and to ensure that these efforts are in place across the various mandating bodies and also to include inspiring clauses as we just heard from USG Guy Ryder in the resolutions having more explicit mention of what is the results, when is it achieved and what is the lifespan, so that these resolutions are not carried into the forever, or at least we could have objective conditionalities under which something is continued or not, so sort of on, off switch.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Additionally, for the environmental pillar, of course, Member States may want to consider how they could delineate better what belongs in the assembly that the General assembly has established, the United Nations Environment assembly, which has the technical skills, the Scientific Secretariat and the environmental mandate related to the United nations and what they may choose to put at unga.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So for us, we very, very much look forward to continuing working on and support the outcome of this working group and to contribute to enhancing the mandate life cycle at this very crucial time for the environment.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you very much.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Cheers.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank Ms. Anderson.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I now give the floor to Ms. Ilse Brands Karis, Assistant Secretary General for Human Rights.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you, Ambassador Wallace.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Dear co Chairs, Excellencies, distinguished delegates, it's my honor to represent the High Commissioner and our Office for Human Rights here today.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I wanted to start with just three small contextual points to bring the perspective of human rights into the discussion.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So obviously this is the focus here, following on previous discussions you've had is the mandate review.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But clearly it relates to impact and prioritization as well as cost effectiveness.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So obviously it links very well into the creation and implementation and efficiency effectiveness strand, as well as the structural programs, of course, also have very, very clear links where human rights is part of it.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: A second point is that the Human rights pillar which we here are talking about, it is of course the office of the High Commissioner as the UN entity, as the secretariat, but the ecosystem, importantly is the Human Rights Council with its universal periodic review, the investigative mechanisms, the special procedures, the mechanisms belonging there, but also the treaty bodies.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So we do have we're talking about both Human Rights Council mandates and GA mandates, including the one that actually established the High Commissioner's mandate itself, the broad one, and to more limited extent, ECOSOC as well, ohchr, you may have noticed, has the largest amount number of mandates cited, 877.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But it should be taken into account that they're very varied.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Some are large, some small, long, continuous, versus those that are specific.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So it takes a differentiated approach to deal with those.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We also have the specificity, as you will know, but still a reminder that the Human Rights Council as well as the Office of the High Commissioner's Headquarters are in Geneva.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So we importantly often need to discuss the link between Geneva and New York, the reinforcement of that link that is needed for consistency and effective use of human rights as mandated by Member states.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And obviously it also this mandate review relates to the Human Rights Council streamlining efforts that the Human Rights Council president has been leading on and of course the Human Rights Council third committee links and the working methods as well as review of status of the Human Rights Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So all of that for context generally, we certainly also have the same categories of concerns that USG Rider already pointed to for review.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And therefore those recommendations from the SG's report are the ones we definitely need to focus on.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Namely the shortcomings in mandate review process and also limited changes even when reviews do take place.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And also the other side, the gaps regarding the system input relating to impact cost effectiveness.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Obviously that is needed as evidence for the reviews linking also to the resources and budget structure issues and the insufficient attention on the adequacy sustainability of resources for mandates that we obviously need to make sure that the results are more visible.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Both of the Human Rights Council with all of the elements I pointed to as well as the Office of the High Commissioner, there have been many successes on the human rights.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Since we're focusing now maybe on challenges.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So just to point that out, obviously both on the norm setting side of it as well as the actual practice of human rights.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But I will here just note because of limits in time the challenges that we are indeed focusing on we have the proliferation of mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We had 39% more mandates in 10 years.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That is a duplication, resource gaps, politicization of reviews as well, which is a concern on human rights specifically the duplication and fragmentation.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: There's multiple mechanisms that cover similar issues, reducing efficiency, visibility, the mandates and USG Rider pointed to this of the Human Rights Council typically do include clauses for review, but that generally range from one to three years.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But renewals nevertheless are often automatic, especially for thematic mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And geographic mandates also are very rarely discontinued.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So we have a review process that lacks rigor and the process influenced at times more by political dynamics rather than a clear and solid impact assessment as is needed clearly.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Also I mentioned the resource gaps, the renewals, if they do in the review, they are doing without the matching resources, not looking at that aspect of it.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So that creates in itself the cycle of implementation deficits.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And obviously that will then impact the impact that assessment that will go into the for that is needed for a solid review.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We also have the reporting overload mechanisms, Human Rights Council mechanisms.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Several of them report both to the Human Rights Council and the General assembly that can duplicate content.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It obviously also increases costs.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So the proposals we have potentially for Member State consideration, especially for the review part here, but we also have other proposals for other discussions.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The High Commissioner had recently a week ago, dialogues with Member States in Geneva.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: He looks forward to exchanging also with Member States in New York.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But there's work that was done under the Human Rights Cluster guided and directed by the SG's proposals and that based on reflections both from the experience and also consultations with Member States as well as other stakeholders experts.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So there is a short non paper for discussion on the Human Rights Council specifically that the High Commissioner has shared with with Member States in Geneva and of course we will be looking forward to also discussions on that when that is opportune.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The other part of those proposals include institutionalizing regular evidence based reviews, especially for mandates exceeding a certain duration, reflecting on the criteria for those reviews of course, including prioritization, differentiation of those continuing long term mandates versus the short term ones and others introducing standardized clauses for review with opportunity for decision on continuation or termination of a mandate consider linking any new mandates to the conclusion of existing ones in the review, consolidate overlapping mandates and consider short term or single report mandates for emerging issues strengthening the cross pillar coordination to ensure mandates reflect integrated priorities across peace, development and human rights and ensure transparent and solidly calculated linkage to resources.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That is again the Geneva coming to New York decisions and the Fifth Committee in particular the linking up on the review and content of IT and of course efficiencies measures reducing duplication and reporting to the Human Rights Council and General assembly considering for instance biannual reporting, virtual presentations and consolidate overlapping mandates in various functions, in particular Protection investigators.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: There are some initiatives underway and we do have a preliminary version for now already of a mandate mapping tool that OHCHR has developed and is continuing to develop further.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It is to support Member States decision making.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It's a comprehensive overview of mandates mechanisms and reports mandated since 2019.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It focuses especially on identifying overlaps and duplication across Human Rights Council mechanisms, treaty bodies and special procedures.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It is meant to inform rationalization and it is obviously relevant for the 2026 review General assembly review as well and I would like to note that it fits very well with the SG's proposed digital mandate registry and AI tools for use.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That tool is already available for Member States to use, but there is a caveat of course it needs further work and development.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We have been doing it within the resources we had.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It needs more investment in it and also in order to link it to the financial side and obviously increased use of AI as well and digital Technology in a more advanced phase as part of the General Assembly.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Another initiative under the way, the resolution 79 192.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The chair of the third committee and the President of the Human Rights Council are working, as many of you know, on a roadmap for the progressive reduction of the number of mandates reporting to each session of the Third Committee.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And in all of this we also have some emerging good practices that we can point to.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Indeed, on this mapping tool, it has been very well received by Member States because obviously it will help to review and also thus streamline the workload.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The application of criteria when reviewing and before renewing mandates is being also further developed, including examining existing results, merging also related mechanisms, integration of existing experts into new inquiries instead of creating entirely new mechanisms is one also initiative underway.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And also we had from the Human Rights Council last session, the consolidation of special procedures mandates in the first, where there was a first merger of two mandates as pointing the way ahead, potentially of course needing also assessment.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So overall I would like to really thank for the opportunity of being here and the great work of this working group on mandates as an opportunity to really push ahead with all of these necessary initiatives, bringing in the perspective of of New York and Geneva in particular, of course, where the human rights bridging is so necessary.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Certainly the Office of the High Commissioner looks forward to engagement with Member States on these and on other issues.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And of course the High Commissioner will hope to also be directly engaging on any follow up and really looking at the UN 80 as the great opportunities and also understanding that time is of the essence.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank Ms. Brands Karris and I'll give the floor to Ms. Claudia Bans, Director, Security Council Affairs Division.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Distinguished Co Chairs, Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this opportunity to share some insights on how the Security Council conducts mandate review.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I must admit I first hesitated when the co Chairs invited me to be part of this panel.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: As the Executive Director of UNEP has already pointed out, the drafting of mandate is a sovereign issue and the prerogative of its members.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The Secretariat is usually not there when Council members negotiate mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: However, we are there when they discuss and take decisions on mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And I'm therefore happy to elaborate a bit about one recent trends in the review and termination of mandates by the Security Council and two the procedures, working methods and tools the Council uses to make these decisions and 3 how the Secretariat, and particularly the Security Council Affairs Divisions or my division, supports the Council in this process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: While the Council has applied an array of approaches to mandate creation, review and termination over its 80 years of decision making.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In my remarks I will focus on the Council's contemporary practice.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We can categorize the Council's review of mandates into three broad approaches.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: First, for most of its practice after the Cold War, the Council has taken a gradual approach to transitions, drawdowns and determination of mandates, guided by recommendations and findings of Secretariat reviews and assessments, and conducted with varying degrees of coordination and consultations with host states and other relevant stakeholders.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The most prominent examples falling under this category are the reconfiguration, drawdown and eventual termination of peace operations in Liberia, Sierra Leone, Coteva, Timor Leste, Nepal and Guinea Bissau among a number of other countries, probably the success stories when there was a.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Staged approach to their drawdown.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Second, the Council has at occasion used time bound mandates with explicitly set deadlines for reviews, drawdowns and eventual mandate termination, some of which include so called sunset clauses.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: This is the case of Somalia and the deployment of the United Special Political Mission, ANTMIS and the African Union led AWSOM Peace Enforcement Mission.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The mandates of these missions include early defined phases of deployment from the very outset, including expected termination dates in the two cases for Antmis it's 2026 and for OSOM it's 2029.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Another example was the creation of the United nations mandate in Colombia in 2016.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It started out with a narrow mandate to support the implementation of the ceasefire and cessation of hostage hostilities, which was later scaled up and transitioned into a mission with a broader mandate to support the implementation of the peace agreement.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The third trend in Council mandate review has been less gradual in approach where major changes or terminations of mandates were made further to requests from host governments or based on case specific considerations of Council members themselves.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In 2023, the Council decided to terminate the mandates of MINUSMA, the Peace Operation in Mali or peacekeeping operation in Mali and unitams in the political mission in Sudan.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Further to request from the host governments Mali and Sudan and in the context of challenging security conditions on the ground.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In 2024, the council did not renew the Mali sanctions regime and thereby effectively terminated the relevant Committee and its Panel of experts.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Similarly, while extending the sanctions regime and the 1718 committee, that's the sanctions committee on DPRK.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: In the same year the Council terminated the mandate of Panel of Experts concerning the Democratic People's Republic of the Korea.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Most recently this year in August, the Council decided to terminate after 40 years of deployment the mandate of UNIFIL as of 31st December 2026.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The Council also indicated possible reconfigurations of UNMAHA, that's the UN Mission in Hudaydah in Yemen and Minerso in Western Sahara in the coming year.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Further to upcoming reviews to be conducted by the Secretariat.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Of specific note are also the sanctions regime, in addition to the ones I have already mentioned, which have been adapted regularly, taking into account improvements in the situation on the ground.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The Secretariat has contributed to these reviews by conducting assessment visits with benchmarks identified benchmarks and this assessment coincided with Council decisions to adjust the measures, particularly in lifting the arms embargo vis a vis the governments in Central African Republic and Somalia.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Now, turning to the Council's working methods, I would like to highlight three practices that are closely tied to how the Council review mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The first is the preparation of the Council's monthly Provisional Program of Work, which is the basic planning tool the Council uses to organize its work.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: While the program I think it's the previous one.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: While the program is agreed upon by Council members on the first working day of the month, this is being prepared with the relevant presidencies at least four months ahead of the actual Presidency.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And this program of work is basically based on it lists all the mandated meetings and mandate renewals and expirations on to which Council members usually add then their elective meetings and signature events.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But the framework of the monthly program is actually based on the mandate and report reporting cycle of the Security Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Although there was a significant increase in so called unscheduled or emergency meetings in the past three years, the mandated activities stemming from previous decisions and existing practice continue to form the overall framework for the monthly schedule in the Security Council as part of its support to Council presidencies and members in preparation of this meeting.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Monthly Program SCAD Our Division maintains and circulates to Member two important planning documents on a monthly basis.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: One is the monthly Forecast.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It's a document that outlines all the upcoming mandate renewals, reports and expirations and the Security Council Reporting and Mandate Cycle that provide the overview on the upcoming reporting and mandate expiration in accordance with previous decisions and existing practice.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: One of the two documents is 100 pages long, but it's structured that you can go month by month, which is useful and for us an indispensable tool to organize the program of work.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Both of these documents are publicly available on the website.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Second, the Council also has, although not a direct correlation to the number of active meeting mandates, but the Council's annual review of the items on its agenda, which is also known as the Summary Statement, is another important way of how Members strive to streamline the work of the Security Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So every first week of January each year, the Secretariat publishes a comprehensive version of the Summary Statement in which the items are divided in two categories.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: One category is those items on the agenda of the Security Council which have been considered by the Security Council in the preceding three years, and the second one is a category that the items have not been considered by the Security Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: This is then reviewed to subject by all by Member States.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And those agenda items which have not been considered are actually due to deletion.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: They will be deleted from the agenda of the Council unless a Member State sends a letter and requests that the agenda item is maintained on the agenda of the Security Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: This process of review was introduced in 1996.
