session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Around 1996. In 1993, there were 207 items on the agenda of the Security Council, and now it's 65.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So in the past 10 years it was around 60 agenda items on the Council's agenda.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The third important aspect of mandate review is the role of penholders in Council decision making and mandate review.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Penholdership is codified in the Presidential Note, and it remains an informal arrangement whereby one or more Council members initiate and chair the informal drafting process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The aim of the penholdership, as described in note 507, was to foster timely initiatives to ensure Council action while preserving the continuity of and with a view to enhancing efficiency in the work of the Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: These penholders, they have a role as conveners of the drafting process and they have significant influence in setting out the methodology and content of mandate reviews in the Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Council members have also encouraged penholders to prioritize the fortune of consensus census, ensure early exchange of information, informal consultations with the broader United nations membership, particularly concerned states to regularly consult the Secretariat and troop and police contributing countries.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Most of the penholders are in the hands of the Permanent members or the P3, but all council members can actually work as penholders or carry out the function of penholders.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The process remains an informal one, although this has been codified in note 507.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And a final point I wanted to mention is about mandate duration in Security Council mandates.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: While most mandates, I think the large majority, particularly those pertaining to peace operations and sanctions regimes, are set for a period of one year.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Others are renewed and reviewed.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: At longer for example UNOCCA, UNAWAS, these are regional offices and the 1267 monitoring team.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: They will be renewed every three years and CTET every four years.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: You also have a number of mandates that have a shorter intervals undof the peacekeeping operation every six months and a number of Other mandates remain, including several peacekeeping operations open ended, as well as some of the sanctions measures.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Open ended peace operations are anmo, gib, anso, anmic, UNRCCA and Anschol sanctions measures, Al Shabaab, Al Qaeda and Yemen and as well as the committees of Guinea Bissau and Iraq, they remain open ended.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I leave it at that.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Co Chairs, thank you again for inviting us.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank Ms. Bands Excellencies, colleagues.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I know that time is now limited for questions.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We have just about 13 minutes to go, so we ask that the questions are succinct to allow for everyone who wants to pose their questions to do so.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We thought it was important for you to hear practical examples of review mechanisms that are already in place across the UN system and good practices that we can contemplate as we go through our process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I will now give the floor to the distinguished PR of Norway.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you very much.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: You've certainly given us a lot to think about, also how this reflects and plays into mandate creation.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But I was struck about something you said, Ilse, about the Human Rights Council.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: If I didn't misunderstand you, and I hope I didn't, I heard that many of the human rights mandates have clauses for review, but that they almost automatically leads to renewal.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And that makes me wondering what the sort of mechanics of the review is, what kind of discussions take place, what kind of reporting or what kind of background does the Council have then to sort of almost automatically renew the mandates?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I thank Norway.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I give the floor now to the distinguished PR of Singapore.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Thank you very much.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Co Chairs, very useful briefing indeed for all of us.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I have actually many questions in my.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Mind.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But let me start perhaps with a question relating to cost.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: When we establish a mandate, there's clearly a cost dimension in terms of a PBI being required.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But when we renew a mandate.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Or. Put it in a default mode where it goes through every year, is there a way of quantifying the cost of not doing a review or not retiring a mandate?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: So my point is that there is a cost for action, but is there a way of quantifying the cost for inaction in terms of mandate review and renewal?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think it's important to make this information available at some point so that delegations who are sovereign indeed, as was pointed out by several of the briefers, will have the relevant information to make decisions in an intergovernmental context.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Second point, also a question.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Is there a way the Secretariat can share actually how many mandates have actually been retired over the last 80 years and in what areas of the three pillars, have these retired mandates taken place?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I mean, obviously the Security Council has a very structured process and it's a much smaller body.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The Human Rights Council, also much smaller than the General Assembly.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Aquasoc as well, has a structured process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The General assembly, because these larger struggles with creating a structured process.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But I think it will be good to see how many mandates have been retired over the last 80 years, in which principal organs and under which pillars.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And a related question, how many retired mandates have come back on the agenda or to a new mandate?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: The reason I ask that question is that it's important to have a permeable system where mandates can be created and retired with fluidity, because right now a lot of delegations would be very concerned about retiring a mandate, because that may be the death of a certain issue.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: But we want to create a more fluid situation that mandates can be renewed or retired.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: It could come back very quickly if needed, so that we assure delegations that retiring mandate is not the end of an issue, but it could be a phase or it could be a pause.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: That's the second comment and question.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: My third question relates to consolidated reviews.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: I think USGuy Rider was talking about how consolidated reviews the exception rather than the norm.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: And could the Secretariat suggest a clustering of agenda items that could potentially be reviewed in a consolidated way in the future and present this to the consideration of Member States?

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: We can then look at it.

session_title: Mandate Review briefing - Panel followed by questions from members of the working group
text: Either disagree with the Secretariat clustering, but I think the idea of a consolidated review of clusters of items with a view to just starting the review process, I think it's an important one.
